article.paragraph: TheCemetery H culturewas a Bronze Age culture in the Punjab, north-western India, from about 1900 BCE until about 1300 BCE. It has been related to both the late phase of theHarappan civilisationHarappan(Indus Valley) civilisation, and theIndo-Aryan migrations.
article.heading: Origins
article.paragraph: The Cemetery H culture was located in and around thePunjab regionin present-dayIndiaandPakistan. It was named after a cemetery found in "area H" atHarappa. Remains of the culture have been dated from about 1900 BCE until about 1300 BCE.

According to Rafique Mughal, the Cemetery H culture developed out of the northern part of theIndus Valley Civilizationaround 1700 BCE, being part of the Punjab Phase,M Rafiq Mughal Lahore Museum Bulletin, off Print, vol.III, No.2, Jul-Dec. 1990one of three cultural phases that developed in theLocalization Eraor "Late Harappan phase" of theIndus Valley Tradition.sfnKenoyer1991asfnShaffer1992According to Kenoyer, the Cemetery H culture "may only reflect a change in the focus of settlement organization from that which was the pattern of the earlier Harappan phase and not cultural discontinuity, urban decay, invading aliens, or site abandonment, all of which have been suggested in the past."sfnKenoyer1991b56According to Kennedy and Mallory & Adams, the Cemetery H culture also "shows clear biological affinities" with the earlier population of Harappa.sfnKennedy2000312sfnMalloryAdams1997103, 310

Some traits of the Cemetery H culture have been associated with theGandhara Grave cutureSwat culture, which has been regarded as evidence of the Indo-Aryan movement toward the Indian subcontinent.sfnMalloryAdams1997103According to Parpola, the Cemetery H culture represents a first wave ofIndo-Aryan migration theoryIndo-Aryan migrationfrom as early as 1900 BCE, which was followed by a migration to the Punjab c. 1700-1400 BCE.sfnParpola1998According to Kochhar, the Swat IV co-founded the Harappan Cemetery H phase in Punjab (2000-1800 BCE), while the Rigvedic Indo-Aryans of Swat V later absorbed the Cemetery H people and gave rise to the Painted Grey Ware culture (to 1400 BCE).sfnKochhar2000185-186

Together with theGandhara grave cultureand theOchre Coloured Pottery culture, the Cemetery H culture is considered by some scholars as a factor in the formation of theVedic civilization.sfnKochhar2000185-186
article.heading: Features
article.paragraph: The distinguishing features of this culture include:http://pubweb.cc.u-tokai.ac.jp/indus/english/3_1_02.html

list.listitem: The use ofcremationof human remains. The bones were stored in painted pottery burial urns. This is completely different from the Indus civilization where bodies were buried in wooden coffins. The urn burials and the "grave skeletons" were nearly contemporaneous.sfnSarkar1964
Reddish pottery, painted in black withantelopes,peacocksetc.,sunorstarmotifs, with different surface treatments to the earlier period.
Expansion of settlements into the east.
Apparent breakdown of the widespread trade of the Indus civilization, with materials such as marine shells no longer used.
Continued use of mud brick for building.

article.heading: Archeology
article.paragraph: Cremation in India is first attested in the Cemetery H culture, which is coincidentally referred to in theVedas. TheRigvedacontains a reference to the emerging practice, inMandala 10RV 10.15.14, where the forefathers "both cremated (agnidagdh-) and uncremated (nagnidagdha-)" are invoked.Dudi, Amar Singh.
